Since many of the components of the project (rehabilitation of port, airport, coastal and river transport, establishment of RTA, sector management and coordination) are located in safe areas, a first phase of the proposed project could be implemented even un- der the situation that existed before the cease-fire.  REPUBLIC OF SIERRA LEONE TRANSPORT SECTOR PROJECT 1. BACKGROUND A. INTRODUCTION I.1 This is the first time that a sector-wide investment approach has been adopted for the sus- tainable development of the transport sector in Sierra Leone. The proposed Intemational Devel- opment Association (IDA) credit, together with pledges from other donors, would help support implementation of the 1996-1999 Transport Sector Investment Program and the proposed Trans- port Sector Project (TSP) jointly developed by the Govemment, sectoral agencies, user groups, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and all donors active in the sector. The main differences between the sector approach and the traditional system of donors negotiating on an individual basis with the Government are that the sector approach: (a) covers the entire sector including mainte- nance as well as the more conventional capital investment, policy reform and institutional issues; (b) has been jointly prepared with local stakeholders (Government and private/public road users) and donors, with the former taking the lead, (c) is supported by all donors active in the sector; (d) makes better use of scarce local resources; and (e) promotes standardized implementation pro- cedures. 1.2 Previous projects supported by the Bank and other donors have attempted to address the issues of a senously deteriorated transport sector and necessary institutional and policy reform on a somewhat piecemeal basis. This project, therefore, adopts a comprehensive sector wide approach as a means of directing and coordinating the efforts of Government and all donors towards sustain- able development. B. MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 1 3 Sierra Leone is a small country (71,740 square kilometers) located on the Atlantic Coast of Afnca. It has a humid, tropical climate with rainfall averaging more than 200 inches per year. The country is hilly to mountainous and traversed by many navigable rivers. It has considerable water resources, a rich soil, ample cultivable land and a climate favorable to the culture of rice and other subsistence crops, as well as cocoa, coffee, palm kemels, piassava and other export cash crops. It is endowed with substantial mineral wealth, particularly large deposits of diamonds (alluvial deposits and kimberlite pipes) and rutile (used in the manufacturing of paints), and sig- nificant deposits of bauxite, iron ore, chromite and gold. 1.4 In spite of these substantial natural resources, Sierra Leone is rated by the United Nations as one of the least-developed and poorest countries in the world. With a population of 4.4 million (1994), growing at an annual average rate of 2.4%, Sierra Leone's per capita income has dwindled to US$150 in 1994 due to the inadequate development efforts and ill-conceived economic policies of the past. Income distribution is uneven and over two thirds of the population live in absolute poverty. Infant mortality is one of the highest in the world (163 per 1,000 live births), and life ex- pectancy among the lowest (40 years ). The economy is based primarily on agriculture and min- ing, which account for 47% and 8% of GDP (1994), respectively. The modem sector is small and
 2 dominated by a few public corporations and private mining concems. It coexists with a largely traditional agricultural sector, which sustains more than two thirds of the population, generally at a bare subsistence level. Since 1991, real per capita income has fallen further, due to the negative impact of the rebel activities on economic activity. Close to 2 million people have been displaced because of the security problems, which has further exacerbated poverty. The population in Freetown, the capital city is estimated to have more than doubled to 1.5 million during the past four years. On top of this, Sierra Leone has to cope with the influx of over 200,000 refugees from Liberia. Many rural areas have been isolated during the conflict and the infrastructure is in disre- pair. 1.5 To reverse past trends, the Government embarked in December 1989 on the daunting task of correcting two decades of economic mismanagement by implementing a significant economic reforms package, which was instrumental in winning back intemational confidence and support. Since 1992, the Govenmment's economic reform program has been implemented with financial sup- port from IDA. The major goals of the structural adjustment program are to lay the foundations for sustainable private sector-led economic growth, and poverty alleviation. The Program com- bines macroeconomic stabilization measures (restrictive monetary and budgetary policies) with structural reforms aimed at liberalizing domestic and foreign trade, reforming the civil service and privatizing/rehabilitating public enterprises. 1.6 The escalation in rebel attacks at the end of 1994 and during the first half of 1995 seri- ously interfered with policy implementation. In particular, rebel attacks led to the closure of the rutile and bauxite mines, drastically reducing foreign exchange receipts and fiscal revenues. Fur- thermore, the uncertainties created by the rebel attacks negatively affected business confidence and general economic activity. This, in tum, caused large revenue shortfalls, in particular in the col- lection of petroleum taxes and custom duties. In addition, emergency defense expenditures in- creased as the Government intensified its campaign against the rebels. As a consequence of these developments, the govemment budget deficit for 1994/95 widened to 7.3% of GDP, compared with a target of 5.2%. Monetary policy, nonetheless, remained on track, largely because of weak pri- vate sector credit demand and active use of open market operations by the central bank. After be- ing reduced to less than 20% in 1993, and 1994, inflation rose to 30% in 1995 as a result of a sharp depreciation of the exchange rate and a jump in the price of imported rice and wheat, adding to the hardship of people already affected by shortages in domestic food production. The interrup- tion of bauxite and rutile exports in early 1995, followed by the loss of diamond export proceeds in mid- 1995, compounded by lower than expected donor flows, gave rise to increasingly severe bal- ance of payments pressures during the course of 1995. In order to avert an unduly sharp deprecia- tion of the exchange rate, the central bank sold foreign exchange and reserves fell to US$10 mil- lion, or 0.9 months of imports, at the end of October 1995. With the significant improvement in the security situation over the past 8 months and national elections of February and March 1996, which resulted in the inauguration of a newly elected democratic Government on March 29, 1996, the Government should be able to restore and intensify the ongoing economic reforms. C. RoLE OF THE TRANSPORT SECTOR IN THE ECONOMY 1.7 The new Government's priorities are to (i) ensure peace and nation-wide security; (ii) reintegrate internally and externally displaced people, refugees and ex-combatants into normal, productive life, and (iii) create an environment for sustained labor-intensive, private sector-led growth. Improvements in physical infrastructure in the transport sector will have a key role in the Government's strategy for achieving these objectives by facilitating the supply response to the
 3 streamnlined incentives that have been implemnented as part of the structural adjustment program. Improvements of rural feeder and trunk roads and in coastal and river transport system would help alleviate poverty by providing market outlets for fanners and increasing food availability. Indi- rectly, through the use of labor intensive methods for road maintenance throughout the country, employment and income opportunities would also improve. Improvement in the transport network will also help integrate the different parts of the country and thus reduce the isolation and depriva- tion that has provided a ground for the rebel insurgency. Implementation of this strategy will re- quire substantial investments in rehabilitation and a strengthening of institutional mechanisms to maintain the newly rehabilitated facilities. 1.8 The proposed TSP will contribute: (a) to enhance country-wide mobility of goods and people and reduce transport costs through maintenance, rehabilitation and reconstruction of the highest priority section of the transportation network, (b) to ensure that the improvements will be sustained by developing and implementing cost recovery policies, building and utilizing local ca- pacity in the public and private sectors, and improving financial management and control; and (c) to strengthen donor coordination. D. THE BANK GROUP'S ASSISTANCE STRATEGY 1.9 Since the resumption of Bank lending to Sierra Leone in 1992, IDA, in conjunction with various cofinanciers, has provided financial support for the Government's program through a Re- construction Import (Credit 2352-SL) and a successor Structural Adjustment (Credit 2546-SL). These credits helped implement an economic reform which facilitated macroeconomic stabilization and economic activity by financing essential support. A public Sector Management Support Proj- ect (Credit 2435-SL) was approved in 1993 to strengthen the Government's capacity to implement structural reforms, particularly in the area of fiscal management. Four investment credits to re- habilitate infrastructure have been approved to supplement these efforts: the first to rehabilitate power supply and distribution (Credit 2356-SL; approved by the Board on April 21, 1992); the second (Credit 245 1-SL, US$45.0 million, January 27, 1993) for the Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project (RRMP), a four-year slice of a seven year road rehabilitation program, at a total cost of over US$93 million, and funded by IDA, AfDB, the European Union (EU), and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP); the third (Credit 251 1-SL, US$26 million, June 10, 1993) for the Freetown Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (FIRP), which includes a compo- nent to rehabilitate some access roads in Freetown; and the fourth (Credit 2702-SL, US$36 mil- lion, April 11, 1995) for the Urban Water Supply Project (UWSP) to rehabilitate and expand the water supply and sewerage system in Freetown. 1.10 IDA's involvement in the TSP is consistent with the broad objectives of the Country As- sistance Strategy (CAS) reviewed by the Board on October 14, 1993, which is to establish a firm basis for sustained private sector-led economic growvth and poverty reduction. The proposed project would directly support the objectives outlined in the CAS by helping to create a supportive environment for resumption of normal economic activity, develop the national construction indus- try, restructure or privatize the principal sector agencies and improve their management and opera- tional efficiency, and support labor-intensive works.
 4 2. THE TRANSPORT SECTOR A. OVERVIEW 2.1 The country's transport sector consists of: (a) about 11,300 km of roads, of which 900 km are paved, over 3,200 km are graveled trunk roads, and 7,200 km are feeder and village access roads; (b) a poorly maintained, over-aged road vehicle fleet of about 52,000 motor vehicles (including motorbikes); (c) a principal sea port located in the capital, Freetown, and two private ports, Niti and Pepel, used primarily for mnineral exports; (d) one major intemational airport (Lungi) and one domestic/regional airport (Hastings) near Freetown and several minor airfields, only two of which are operational; and (e) about 400 km of shallow but navigable river stretches, although river transport remains insignificant. Sierra Leone's rail network was phased out during the early 1970s when it became uneconormic. The national road network classification, together with statistics of the transport sector (vehicles, traffic accidents, port and air transport), are shown in Annex 2- 1. 2.2 Road Infrastructure. The road network is the dominant intemal transport mode account- ing for over 80% of the domestic traffic flows, with the rest being carried on waterways. The length and coverage of the Sierra Leone's road network is satisfactory. However, the quality re- mains below acceptable standards after two decades of neglect and inadequate maintenance largely due to lack of funding, poor maintenance practices and institutional weaknesses. The density of the total road network at 2.8 km/I000 inhabitants is above the average of 1.17 km for Sub-Sahara Af- rica and above the average of 1.20 km in Nigeria and 2.0 km in Ghana. Paved main roads link Freetown with most district centers, with the exception of Kabala in the North and Kailahun in the East. However, a few fertile rural areas previously served by the now defunct railroad still need connections to the road network. Due to t'e past under-allocation of funds for maintenance, nearly 30% of the paved roads, 55% of the gravel and 70% of the earth roads are rated in poor to very poor condition and are near collapse. As a result, the country is estimated to incur an additional cost of $35 million per annum in vehicle operating costs, which could be avoided if the roads were properly maintained. The former Department of Works (DOW) managed the road network until early 1993, when this responsibility was devolved to the Sierra Leone Roads Authority (SLRA) 2.3 Road Transport. Road transport is almost entirely operated by small private operators. There is free market entry for operator of trucks or passenger vehicles, subject to minimal registra- tion and licensing requirements. Passenger fares and freight tariffs in the private sector are not regulated in practice, although the tariffs charged by the Sierra Leone Road Transport Corporation (SLRTC), a public authority, are subject to Government control. The national vehicle fleet com- prises approximately 43,000 vehicles, including about 25,000 private cars, 6,000 taxis, 3,600 trucks, 1,000 buses and 7,300 jeeps and vans. Most vehicles are imported used; spares are expen- sive. Drivers are poorly trained. Many roads and streets are in dire condition. The vehicle fleet is poorly maintained and inefficient. 2.4 The unreliable supply and poor quality of public passenger transport cause considerable hardship to the middle and low-income public who must rely on it. While some of the country's areas remained isolated during the war, buses are overloaded with long waiting time and frequent delays because of breakdowns. These problems are compounded in the Freetown area by lack of traffic management and poor road conditions, resulting in constant traffic congestion. It is ex- pected that these problems will be alleviated by the current rehabilitation program covering most streets in the Commercial Business District (CBD) of Freetown.
 5 2.5 SLRTC operates a fleet of 30 buses and currently has less than a 5% share of the passen- ger transport. Its buses are operated mostly in Freetown due to the security situation, although normally about half would be assigned to inter-city routes. SLRTC's tariffs provide concessional rates for school children and women. The corporation operates at a loss due to low tanffs for sev- eral services provided as public service obligations, but also because of inefficient management, high operating costs partly due to poor road conditions, and a shortage of spares which reduces fleet availability. It does not receive revenue subsidies, but the Government has passed on limited bilateral assistance in the form of buses, spares and technical assistance to the corporation on con- cessional terms. Although SLRTC's performance has improved somewhat during the past two years, the overall situation in public passenger transport has worsened because of the influx of refugees into Freetown. 2.6 Non-motorized transport, such as bicycles, cycles trailers and other types, are not widely used in Sierra Leone, though they would provide sustainable low-cost transport, particularly for the rural and urban poor. The on-going RRMP, financed by IDA and other donors, includes a pi- lot component to promote the use of non-motonzed transport based on recent Bank experience in Ghana. 2.7 Port Facilities and Traffic. The main port of Sierra Leone is located in Freetown, in a natural harbor which permits a draft of almost 10 meters. There are six public berths (quay length 1,100 m), five transit sheds and a total area of 32 acres, workshops and a small dockyard Sepa- rate dedicated terminals handle petroleum and fish traffic, both of which are also handled at an- chorage. Freetown port handles most of the country's general cargo and all of its petroleum import traffic. The ports of Niti and Pepel are loading wharves for bulk exports (up to 1.0 million tons/year of bauxite and rutile). These exports were interrupted by rebel incursions in early 1995 and the ports have not been operated since. Total dry cargo traffic through the public berths at Freetown in 1995 was 451,000 tons, down from 638,000 tons in 1979. It has been fairly static over the last six years. Exports are negligible. Fourteen percent of traffic is in bulk, 56% is con- ventional break-bulk; 30%, which is almost all cargo suitable for containers, is containerized. The port facilities are in a general need of rehabilitation, specially the main quay, the dockyard, port roads and storage areas; some obsolete cargo-handling equipment also needs to be replaced. Op- erational performance on cargo handling is average (400 tons per ship day on general cargo, 600 to 900 tons on bags, 10 to 12 containers per hour), but not markedly low by the standards of similar ports on the West African Coast. 2.8 Port Administration. Since 1964, the port of Freetown is managed by the Sierra Leone Ports Authority (SLPA). established as a statutory public corporation administered by a Board of Directors, to develop and operate the port in the public interest. It is also responsible for all marine and shore services in the country and has some regulatory role in maritime administration. It is under close supervision of MTCE. SLPA operates the port as a service port, conducting pilotage, stevedoring, cargo handling and storage on force account and has its own workshop and slipway. Niti and Pepel were operated by the mining companies, which paid pilotage fees and channel dues to the SLPA. SLPA has been managed for nearly ten years under a consultancy, advisory and training services contract with foreign consultants. Expatriates are still in most of SLPA's execu- tive positions. IDA reviewed SLPA's management during the implementation of the RIC and found it to be in need of restructuring and improvement as discussed in Chapter 5. 2.9 Ferry Services. By order of Government, SLPA operates and finances the ferry service between Freetown and Tagrin (about 8 kIn), which provides a vital link between the capital and
 6 Lungi International Airport and the north-west region. The alternative to this ferry service is a 180-km road detour via Masiaka and Port Loko. The fleet has consisted of two 600-ton ferries dating from 1981, both of which have recently been retired from service, and one fairly moden second hand vessel (486 tons) purchased in 1993 from Greece. 210 employees from SLPA work in ferry services (19% of the SLPA workforce). Two additional passenger ferries are needed to en- sure continued adequate services. The Government plans to commission a feasibility study, to be financed by AfDB, of a shorter road to Lungi, by-passing Port Loko; this would reduce the road distance to the airport to 100 kIn, and would necessitate the construction of two bridges. Con- struction would be a major project and its economic viability will have to be considered careflly. 2.10 Shipping and Manitime Administration. The government-owned Sierra Leone National Shipping Companv (SLNSC) now operates only as a shipping agent, freight forwarder and slot charterer in competition with private firms. It collects from importers and shippers a freight levy of US$1.50 per ton of cargo on imports and US$0.60 per ton of export, based on the 1965 Geneva Convention (Code of Conduct of Conferences). The levy, which had been used to finance Mari- time Administration expenses, is no longer used for this purpose and now accrues to general reve- nues. 2.11 Coastal and River Transport This form of transport is used to barge bauxite and rutile ores from Niti to Sherbro Island for transshipment to ocean-going vessels; and to serve the Kambia and Port Loko districts of the Northem region. Its share of the domestic transportation market has increased to around 20% especially since road transport has been constrained by rebel activities. It is estimated that total navigable distance is 400 km for vessels of 2.0 meter draft throughout the year, taking advantage of favorable tides. Also, Pampers (local boats) are operated by several small private operators and are not regulated. No operating data are available on this mode of transport. A study recently completed by consultants recommended a program for the rehabilita- tion and construction of jetties and landing sites, including training for proper maintenance of the facilities and safe operations of vessels. 2.12 Air Transport. Sierra Leone's only intemational airport is located at Lungi, reached mainly by a one-hour ferry/road connection from Freetown. Lungi Intemational Airport is man- aged by the Sierra Leone Airports Authority (SLAA), a statutory corporation established in 1988 with UNDP assistance. SLAA is managed efficiently and is operating on a commercial basis at a profit. However, extensive repair and modermization of navigational aids, landing lights, pavement and perimeter fencing are urgently required. 2.13 After two decades of steady growth, international air traffic has declined from 133,000 in 1991 to 113,000 passengers in 1994 because of the prevailing insecurity. Intemational travel is offered by two major international carriers, KLM and Sabana, and EAS, which exploits the traffic rights of the Sierra National Airlines (SNA). Several regional African airlines provide service to the neighboring countries. Due to the security situation, intemal air travel services by helicopter are currently available between Freetown and a few other major towns. B. TRANSPORT SECrOR ORGANIZATION 2.14 Private and Public Sector Roles. The private sector is dominant in the road and coastal and river transport subsectors. Except for the extended management contract, the private sector plays no role in the port sector; it is represented in the shipping subsector by shipping and forward- ing agents. The public sector is currently responsible for road construction and maintenance with
 7 major works camred out by private, mostly foreign, contractors. It manages ports and airports, including commercial activities such as stevedoring in port and aircraft handling in airports. It has small shares in freight forwarding (SLNSC), intemational air transport (SNA), and road transport (SLRTC). With the exception of SLRTC, all transport parastatals operate at a profit, and withut direct subsidies from the Government, but inadequate maintenance and renewal of equipmat have resulted in decapitalization. 2.15 Sector Administration. Transport sector administration was, until recently, divided be- tween the Department of Transport and Communications (DOTC), which supervises SLPA, SLAA, SLRTC and SLNSC and has responsibility for civil aviation, and the Department of Works (DOW) which oversees SLRA. Under the recently elected democratic Government, the DOTC has been transformed into the new Ministry of Transport, Communications and the Environment (MTCE) that will oversee all public transport sector entities, except SLRA which is under the new Ministry of Works and Technical Maintenance (MWTM). MTCE is charged with initiating poli- cies, regulations, and transport sector development plans for the country. With Bank assistance through Project Preparation Facilities (P-872-SL and 872-1-SL), MTCE's Coordination and Monitoring Unit (CMU) has been strengthened and its supervisory role has correspondingly besn enhanced and made more effective. 2.16 The reform of Sierra Leone's road sector management has become a model in Africa, par- ticularly with (a) the creation of a commercially-oriented organization responsible for road man- agement, and (b) the creation of a road fund, financed from user charges/fuel levy, to cover the cost of road maintenance. The former DOW administered public roads until 1992/93 when this re- sponsibility was devolved to the newly established SLRA in a far-reaching road sector reform pro- gram supported by IDA under the RRMP. DOW was overstaffed at the non-professional level, with about 12,000 staff in January 1992. Excess staff at DOW have been retrenched. It now has less than 1,000 employees. Some engineers and technicians have been employed by SLRA, while others have become small maintenance contractors. The organization, managaeent and finances of SLRA, SLAA and SLPA are discussed in Chapter 5. C. FiSCAL ISSUES AND AFFORDABaIrry 2.17 To estimate the financial contribution of the transport sector to the economy, the revenues generated by the various parastatals were calculated. In 1994/95, the sector as a whole generated about US$13 million and about US$1 million equivalent in gross and net revenues for services provided by SLPA, SLAA, SLNSC, and SLRTC. However, revenue generation is misleading since it results partly from lack of maintenance and renewal of facilities and equipment. In fact, there is loss of substance and decapitalization. There are no subsidies from the govenment to the sector organizations; however, SLRTC received funds in 1994 from the Freight Levy for the pur- chase of buses, thus obtaining an indirect subsidy. But SLPA has been subsidizing the Govem- ment for years (in some cases through tax compensation) by financing ferry acquisition and making good for the deficit of ferry operations. There is no formal agreement between the Government and SLPA, which is lacking for management purposes. While the sector as a whole is a net contributor to the economy, the revenues generated could be substantially increased. 2.18 Road Fund. A Road Fund was initially set up in 1989 through a cabinet decision to fi- nance road maintenance work nationwide through various user fees. It was subsequently incorpo- rated in the SLRA Act in 1992, which stipulated the creation of this Road Fund for the collection of: (a) road user charges levy on fuel; (b) vehicle licensing fees; (c) vehicle registration fees; and
 8 (d) any other road user charges that may from time to time be allocated to the fund by law, toll charges, for instance. The proceeds from this fund are intended specifically to defray expenses for routine, periodic and emergency road maintenance. It was anticipated that rehabilitation and re- construction and backlog maintenance would be supported by foreign funding, while road user fees would cover all regular maintenance needs of the network. As agreed under the RRMP, fuel levy was raised to US $0.08 per liter equivalent (or Le 200 per Ig) in December 1994. But with the depreciation of the Leone since then, the fuel levy has now been reduced to US$0.05 per liter equivalent. 2.19 The current revenue of the Road Fund is inadequate for financing routine and periodic maintenance of the road network; it is estimated that the current levy would only cover 30-50% of the planned ten year maintenance program of the national road system, totaling 8,200 km. It should be noted that this levy does not cover the routine and periodic maintenance costs of local roads and streets, totaling 3,000 km. An analysis of the revenue structure of the Road Fund is shown in Chapter 5. 2.20 At present, the fuel levy is the sole source of funding for the Road Fund, other fees are collected by the Road Transport Department (RTD) of MTCE for vehicle examination and com- mercial authorization, and the Police Department for license, registration and issuance of driver's licenses. The collection system for various fees is inefficient and inadequate. To overcome the limitations imnposed by an uncoordinated system of fee collection and to establish the linkage be- tween road usage and road maintenance expenditure, the Government is proposing the following changes: (a) the collection of various road transport fees by different agencies will be transferred and undertaken by the new Road Transport Authority (RTA), and (b) vehicle related user charges, such as vehicle registration, vehicle exammnation arid license fees, will be channeled into the Road Fund beginning January 1, 1997. D. LESSONS LEARNED FROM BANK GROUP AND OTHER DONORS 2.21 The Bank has financed three operations in the transport sector, all highway projects, which were signed in 1971, 1981 and 1993. The First Highway Project financed the construction of the Bo-Kenema road and the first phase of a road maintenance program. The project experienced de- lays and cost overruns. The Project Performance Audit Report (PPAR) in 1978 noted an ex-post economic return of 25%, higher than at appraisal, and that the project's achievements in routine and periodic maintenance were far below targets. The Second Highway Project focused on the rehabilitation of 800 km of trunk roads and on improving routine and periodic maintenance, with cofinancing from AfDB and the OPEC Fund. The project was completed in 1988, after delays and suspensions due to the Government's defaults in repayment of past debts. The Project Completion Report (PCR) in 1991 noted that only about 55% of the physical works were completed, with long delays in execution, poor performance by the Borrower and serious interruptions in counterpart funding. However, a post-evaluation of the resealed and regravelled roads indicated a satisfactory economic intemal rate of return (ERR) of 60%. 2.22 The ongoing RRMP, with cofinancing from AfDB, EU, and UNDP, focuses on trunk road rehabilitation and maintenance, strengthening of road management institutions, promotion of pilot non-motorized transport and support to transport sector institutions. It took account of the lessons leamed from previous operations including: establishment of an autonomous commercially- oriented agency with substantially reduced labor force (SLRA); creation and maintenance of a road fund to ensure adequacy and timeliness of counterpart funding; and providing for a shift from
 9 maintenance by force account to maintenance by contract and for training of domestic contractors. Project implementation has been on schedule, except for two major road contracts having been terminated due to rebel attacks. 2.23 Building on the successful expenrences of the RRMP, the proposed transport sector in- vestment project will deepen and reinforce the reforms already achieved or in progress in the road subsector and will generalize the approach to the rest of the transport sector. The main lessons include, the establishment of commercially oriented, semi-autonomous authorities for each of the transport subsectors, with management shielded from political interference and with sustained budgetary resources derived from user fees on the use of transport infrastructures, adequate staff compensation and incentives, emphasis on coitract execution of works and subcontracting to the private sector, and introduction of labor intensive maintenance methods. Technical assistance is being provided for line positions with time-based plans for transfer of knowledge to local staff. Emphasis is on cost recovery and enhancement of the transport sector coordination and monitoring capacity. 2.24 Donor coordination has been improving through existing cofinancing arrangements. It has been further strengthened during the preparation of the proposed TSP through donor meetings with the Government and stakeholders in 1994 and 1995. The Government will organize similar confer- ences each year to streamline dialogue with donors and report on progress of implementation of the proposed project, review projected plans for subsequent years, and to seek additional funding. The Government intends to adopt common arrangements for implementation, monitoring, accounting, and reporting for all donor assisted project components. Understanding has been reached that these common arrangements will be detailed in the project implementation manual and reviewed with IDA before being presented to the donors at the first donor conference scheduled before December 1, 1996. 3. TRANSPORT SECTOR POLICY A. OVERALL TRANSPORT SECTOR POLICY 3. 1 In June 1994, the Government of Sierra Leone organized a workshop to develop a national transport sector policy. The workshop included all major stakeholders -- Government, parastatals, private sector and intemational donors -- having a stake in the development of Sierra Leone's transport sector. The workshop was highly participative and resulted in a basic consensus on the majors goals and objectives for each transport subsector (road infrastructure, road transport, water transport and air transport). Based on this consensus, DOTC's Planning Unit completed in March 1995, after reviews by the major stakeholders, a draft National Transport Policy, consistent with national economic reforms objectives, and compatible with available domestic and intemational aid resources. The National Transport Policy presents the Government's medium-term objectives and action plan for the sector. It was approved by the Government and presented to a Donors' Meeting in June 1995. It is the basis for the Transport Policy Letter, dated April 24, 1996, shown in An- nex 3-1, and for the four-year investment program for the transport sector discussed in Chapter 4. 3.2 The overall goal of the National Transport Sector Policy is to rehabilitate the transport infrastructure, and transform it into an efficient, reliable, safe, environment-friendly, equitable and
 10 self-reliant system, capable of supporting a sustainable private-sector led economic growth, assist- ing in poverty alleviation and rehabilitation of the war-affected areas. 3.3 The Government's main objectives are to put the management and financing of the roads, road transport, ports, and airport, on a sustainable long-term basis, managed with commercial principle and to clear the large backlog of rehabilitation and maintenance works in the transport infrastructure systemn. To this end, it has adopted the following objectives: (i) clear the backlog of rehabilitation and maintenance of the road network an increase labor-intensive works; (ii) base transport sub-sector investment decisions on economic and environmental analyses; (iii) ensure adequacy of funds for routine and penodic maintenance via user charges; (iv) improve cost recov- ery in all transport sector parastatals to ensure sustainability; (v) vigorously promote private sector participation in the execution of works and delivery of transport services; (vi) reduce dependence on foreign technical assistance and increase training and perfonnance of local staff; (vii) improve capacity to assess the financial, economic and environmental impacts of alternate transport infra- structure investment strategies; (viii) streamline regulations and effectively enforce them; (ix) cre- ate institutional capacity to monitor, collect, and analyze transport data and information; (x) create capacity for sector coordination, policy formulation and planning; and (xi) strengthen donor coor- dination. B. INSTITUTIONAL REFORM 3.4 In order to improve the overall operational efficiency and service quality of the transport sector, the Government's goal is to re-engineer the sector, based on a new definition of the respec- tive roles of Government, commercially-run autonomous agencies and the private sector. In such a concept, the Government no longer is directly involved in running transport services, unless they are strategic or there is no private candidate to perform these services. The role of the Government is redefined to: (i) a regulating role, seting up and enforcing a clear set of standards and regula- tions pertaining to safety, energy, environmental protection, as well as market entry and exit condi- tions and competition rules; (ii) a provider of basic infrastructure (as opposed to transport serv- ices); and (iii) developing the transport policy. Regulatory functions are performed by semi- autonomous agencies funded by user fees, with users represented on the Boards. Basic infrastruc- ture services are provided on a commercial basis by existing parastatals. Transport services would be commercialized or privatized, whenever feasible. 3.5 In the new organizational setting, the primary role of the MTCE will be to develop and oversee transport policy and to coordinate and monitor semi-autonomous agencies, each responsi- ble for a transport mode. Its current organizational structure is shown in Annex 3-2. The Ministry would be streamlined to a CMU, a number of semi-autonomous transport sector agencies and authorities, and an Environmental Department. The terms of reference of the CMU are included in the Project Files. 3.6 As mentioned in para. 2.15, the transport sector organization of Sierra Leone has already been substantially modernized through staff reduction and the creation of semi-autonomous com- mercial authorities in charge of the key transport subsectors for roads, ports and airports. How- ever, in the past, the capacity to develop sector policies and to coordinate and oversee the activities of the authorities by the parent ministries was very limited. Efforts, which were made under RRMP to enhance the capacity of the Planning Unit at the former DOTC failed to aclieve signifi- cant results. The lack of a transport sector policy and of oversight capacity by the previous parent
 I1 rninistnres led to uncoordinated plans in the various transport subsectors, with potential conflicts and waste of investments. C. TRANSPORT SUBSECTOR POLICIES 3.11 Road Infrastructure. The principal goal for road infrastructure subsector is to rehabili- tate the national road system to an acceptable level of serviceability and to maintain it in good condition, so that it can fulfill its strategic role in the development of the national and local economies. The main objectives of SLRA are: (i) to have the entire National Road System under a regular, sustainable program of routine and periodic maintenance by 2005; (ii) to bring at least 60% of the pnrmary network (2,000 km) to a paved standard and at least 60% of the secondary
 12 network to all-weather standard; (iii) to complete the Sierra Leonean portion of the Trans-West Africa Highway to adequate paved standard by the year 2010; (iv) to complete the construction of permanent bridges, where economic, on all main roads by 2005; and (v) to continue to upgrade the tertiary network to gravel surfacing to improve year-around access to important agricultural and mineral productive areas. 3.12 There has been some capacity increase in the private construction industry with the train- ing of ten labor based contractors under the ongoing IDA-financed Agricultural Sector Support Project (Credit 1501 -SL). Under the new policy, SLRA will continue to move from force account to contract execution of works and further encourage the development of small domestic firms ca- pable of bidding on small routine and periodic maintenance contracts involving labor-intensive works. To encourage the development of small contracting firms, bids will be called for on a con- sistent basis. This will provide firms with the incentive to gradually build up small equipment holdings, so that they can eventually bid for larger works. This would be accompanied by continu- ing the current personnel training and hiring out of tools and equipment to develop such firms. Routine maintenance is executed almost entirely by one-man contractors. The proposed project would support the development of another ten labor-based contractors and medium-size contrac- tors. Up to 90% of the planned periodic maintenance program will eventually be executed by these contractors. 3.13 With respect to road user fees and cost recovery, the Government will adjust and monitor closely fuel levy revenues and examine the adequacy of the levy level, and gradually adjust road user charges to fully cover the costs of routine and periodic maintenance (paras. 5.5 to 5 .1 1 ). 3.14 Road Transport. Under the new policy, the main objectives for road transport are: (i) to set up a new autonomous RTA financed by user fees and responsible for developing and imple- menting the road transport policy, specifying vehicle standards licensing of dnrvers, vehicles and transport services firms, monitoring the subsector and pricing policies, (ii) to establish a clear set of safety, energy and environmental standards, and traffic regulations; (iii) to develop comprehen- sive and effective enforcement programs for violations of road-related laws and standards, (iv) to encourage the growth of the private sector in road transport services, private maintenance and in- spection services and contracting of maintenance services for government vehicles and through the privatization of SLRTC. The organizational structure of RTA is shown in Annex 3-3. 3.15 Maritime and Water Transport. The main objectives under the new policy are: (i) to redefine the role of Government in the subsector as regulator and provider of basic infrastructure services and delegate to a semi-autonomous Marine Services Administration the coordination and regulation of all marine, coastal and inland water transport activities; (ii) to improve the efficiency of SLPA, including reorganization of the authority into autonomous profit centers or companies (maritime services, harbour operations, ship repair, ferry), and the commercialization and/or pos- sible privatization of certain services; (iii) to improve cost recovery of maritime administration; (iv) to comply with intemational maritime standards and inmprove intemational maritime coopera- tion; (v) to complete the privatization of SLNSC, and (vi) to rehabilitate the coastal and river transport infrastructure, where feasible. 3.16 Air Transport. The main objectives under the new policy are: (i) to reorganize the overall administration of the air transport subsector by restructuring the MTCE's Directorate of Civil Aviation and transforming it into a semi-autonomous Civil Aviation Agency, to be financed from aviation-related users fees; (ii) to strengthen the SLAA as a semi-autonomous, commercial,
 13 self-sustained provider of airport infrastructure services with funding based on airport users fees; (iii) unbundle functions that can be more efficiently contracted out to the private sector, (iv) to re- habilitate and maintain Lungi Intemational Airport to Intemational Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) safety standards; (iv) to improve security and safety at Hastings and remaining operational airfields, whenever it is cost-effective; and (v) to privatize SNA. 4. BENEFITS AND ECONOMIC RETURNS 6.2 The project's direct, tangible but unmeasurable benefits are as follows: * improved, transparent sector management, including more effective management and monitoring of sector parastatals and their operations on a commercial basis; * increased direct private sector participation in road maintenance, waterway transpor- tation, port and airline operations, and vehicle examination; and indirect private sec- tor participation through user representation on the boards of transport parastatals; * through a steady volume of road maintenance works, expanded capacity of small and medium construction enterprises and of local consultants in project preparation, im- plementation, auditing and supervision; * training of skilled and unskilled labor, which can move to other construction activi- ties;

Economic internal rates of return (ERR) calculations and sensitivity analysis are estimated in Annex 6-1 for the road infrastructure, road transport, port rehabilitation, water transport and the air transport components, and summarized as follows: (a) Road Infrastructure Component: The cost-benefit analysis for the IDA-financed portion of the Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Program was carried out us- ing data on road and traffic collected by SLRA. Benefits were approximated by savings in vehicle operating costs. The road component has an overall EIRR of 25% and NPV of US$8.0 million discounted at 12%, with all subcomponents yielding EIRRs greater than 12%, except for a few sections classified as gravel main roads. These sections are expected to yield higher EIiRRs if uncaptured benefits to farmers are incorporated. The non [DA-financed portion of the pro- gram is estimated to yield EfRRs between 12% to 40%. Sensitivity analyses indi- cate that the overall EIRR of the road component would decrease to 22% if there is a cost overrun of 10%, and to 17% if project implementation is delayed by one year. (b) Road Transport Component: Economic retums were calculated for the IDA- financed component of road transport. Benefits were quantified by saving in transportation in terms of time and vehicle operation costs. The ERR is 25% and NPV is $1.6 million, discounted at 12%. The result of the sensitivity analysis shows that the base ERR decreases from 25% to 23 with a 10% cost-overrun and to 21% with a one-year implementation delay. (c) Port Rehabilitation Component: The cost-benefit analysis was carried out for the IDA-financed component of port rehabilitation, the paving of the unsurfaced areas of the port and a program of deferred maintenance. Benefits were approximated by savings in operation and maintenance costs. This component has an overall EIRR of 24% and NPV of US$7.1 million discounted at 12%. This return would be reduced to 22% if there is a cost-overrun of 10%, and to 20% if project imple- mentation is delayed by one year. (d) Coastal and River Transport Component. Economic retums were calculated for a sample of 12 out of 77 landings studied. Benefits were calculated from vessel, passenger, handling and spoilage savings. Five typical landings in Phase I invest- ment were analvzed. These calculations show ERRs ranging from 16% to 97% for the selected locations. Sensitivity analyses against risks of 10% cost-overrun and 10% decrease in benefits still supported the viability of these landings.

USA Dear Mr. Wolfensohn, Re: Sierra Leone - Proposed Transport Sector Project - Letter of Sector Policies Our Ministry has been working with your staff on the Transport Sector Project which is due to go to the IDA Board in June 1996. In order to place this project in its proper policy context and in advance of its presentation to the Board, we are writing to inform the Intemational Development Association of the initiatives we are currently taking in the transport sector in Sierra Leone. Govemment attaches high priority to the sector's role in increasing human welfare and economic growth. This letter therefore highlights the main constraints facing the sector and the strategies designed to address them. This policy and strategy framework will be used to underpin the design and implementation of the proposed IDA-supported Transport Sector Project (TSP), as well as other donor supported projects. Backeround The transport sector in Sierra Leone is currently characterized by inadequate infrastructure and inefficient services; poor maintenance practices, an ineffective inland water transport system; continued impediments by non-physical barriers such as inappropriate policies, excessive regulation, and cumbersome procedures, all of which inhibit efficient traffic flow; inadequate and undeveloped indigenous capabilities to plan, design, manage, and operate the sector; the absence of reliable data for planning and application of modem management systems; and obsolete regulatory rules which were inherited from the colonial period. In view of the shortcomnings listed above, a fundamental transport policy reform is essential to increase the role and operational significance of transport in the economnic development process. A reformed and well - structure transport sector can help reduce the drain on public funds and raise the level of savings by charging tariffs and rates that cover the cost of services, and by transferring transport services to private enterprises, thereby releasing public funds for other uses. Similarly,
 42 Annex 3-1 Page 2 of 6 the sector could strike an optimal balance between construction, rehabilitation and maintenance, ensuring that no investments are undertaken that do not have an acceptable economic rate of retum. In addition, the sector could increase its own efficiency by improving the management o its human resources and physical facilities, by promoting competition, and by increasing the use of the private sector for maintenance and construction works. In this way, the transport sector could also contribute some funds to supplement the Government's investment in the sector. STRATEGIES AND ACTIONS Transport Sector Coordination. Government is seeking to improve the operational efficiency, service quality, and availability of transport services by implementing appropriate policies and administrative measures that will increase their competitiveness, productivity, and profitability, while at the same time ensuring social and economic development. In pursuit of the above, the following lines of action are proposed:- strengthening of the Co-ordination and Monitoring Unit at the Ministry of Transport Communications and the Environment in terms of trained manpower and logistics support by the creation of an advisory unit (comprising of Transport Economist and a graduate Data Analyst) financed from a percent levy on transport sector revenue and staffed with Sierra Leonean professionals who are employed on contract and paid competitive salaries; establishing standard reporting and audit formats for the various transport-related parastatals; the issuance of a manual on the qualifications, code of conduct, and performance of Board Members of these parastatals; reviewing the Transport Sector Policy periodically and monitoring its implementation; and transport sector donor co-ordination. Financin!flnvestment. In the short and medium term, govemment proposes to establish efficient methods of resource mobilization to ensure sustainability of the project of rehabilitation and expansion of the transport sector; establish a Resource Mobilization Committee comprising the Ministries of Transportation Communications and the EnWoronment; Finance; Development and Economic Planning; Foreign Affairs; and Work and Technical Maintenance which will draw up programmes and seek funding, locally and intemationally; introduce user fee charges for services; and establish subsidy criteria. Transport services will also be improved through the promotion of enterprises, the liberalization of services, and the creation of an enabling framework for strengthening the private sector. Manpower Development. Govemment intends to promote human resources planning, development, and utilization in order to improve the quality and availability of personnel at all levels for efficient management and operation of transport modes. Along these lines the following actions will be undertaken:- training of personnel in all transport fields, improvement of conditions of service and career opportunities; provision of opportunities for national experts; establishment and adequate funding of training institutions locally; provision of opportunities for specialized training overseas; and, promotion of exchange programmes for local personnel. Roads Infrastructure. The overall of the roads infrastructure policy is to rehabilitate and maintain, in good condition, the existing road network nation-wide, in order to maximize its contribution to the economic development programme. The objectives are to remove physical bottflenecks in the road network in order to unleash a strong supply response in support of the econonic recovery programme, through rehabilitation and maintenance; to build institutional capacity to improve management and planning and to foster market-oriented policies, to strengthen road infrastructure institutions by restructuring if necessary, to provide an independent source of
 43 Annex 3-1 Page 3 of 6 funding through user fees, to encourage new methods of infrastructure rehabilitation, using appropriate labour-intensive technologies and local resources and inputs, in order to generate jobs and provide a sustainable maintenance system; to increase the role of the private sector in road maintenance, and develop the capacity of small and medium-sized local contractors to perform road maintenance. The actions to be undertaken will include the implementation of phased and balanced programmes of development and management of roads infrastructure, taking into account the needs and requirements of the production and marketing centres, rehabilitation, upgrading, and maintenance of the most critical elements of the existing roads infrastructure so as to improve their efficiency and capacity utilization, as well as to prolong their economic life, and assessment of the adequacy of the existing road network in terms of geographic distribution, integration with other modes, and responsiveness to road transport demands. In the area of user fee pricing and cost recovery, government will closely monitor fuel levy revenues and examine the adequacy of the levy level; gradually adjust road user charges to fully recover the costs of routine and penrodic maintenance; pay directly to the Road Fund all fees collected by the Road Transport Authority (vehicles and drivers license fees, vehicle examination and registration fees, and commercial authorization fees), examine other local sources of funding and contributions in kind; develop local sources of funding for the construction, rehabilitation and mostly maintenance of rural feeder roads in connection with local communities; and develop cooperation with the Intemational Labou (rganization (1LO) and Non-Government Organizations (NGOs). To facilitate institutional strengthening, action will be taken to provide logistic support to SLRA in the form of vehicles and improved office equipment and facilities, provide Technical Assistance to SLRA at all levels of management, continue to develop tiie Road Infrastructure Management Information System, and develop and implement better planning techniques to optimize the road investment programme, taking into consideration network planning or optimization techniques and economic rates of return on investment. In the field of human resources development, the following programmes are planned: the implementation of the Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project (RRMP) human resources and training programme, development of civil engineering, and other transport planning and management curncula in Sierra Leone's institutions of leaming, and the formulation of training programmes for private road maintenance contractors. In an effort to facilitate private sector development, private road contractors will be encouraged through the award of small road maintenance contractors, using labour-intensive technologies, training programmes for contractors, and leasing of equipments to contractors. Environmental protection and control will be ensured by the following measures: a review of transport investment programmes to determine which road projects are likely to have a significant impact on the environment: the commissioning of an environmental impact study in the design phase for these projects, taking action to preserve arable lands, restrict deforestation, preserve natural areas (classified forests, animal reserves and parks, tourist and archaeological sites); undertaking reforestation, in conjunction with road infrastructure works, giving close attention to air pollution in the cities, mostly Freetown, and creating and maintaining in SLRA an in-house
 44 Annex 3-1 Page 4 of 6 environmental division with its engineering staff in charge of environmental impact assessment and monitoring. Road Transport. The main goal of this subsector is to establish a road transport system that will be available, safe, reliable, efficient, cost effective, sustainable, and capable of facilitating the exploitation and evacuation of resources and the movement of persons within and between towns. In order to reach these goals, Sierra Leone's policy in the Road Transport Subsector will focus on the following objectives: the creation of an autonomous user financed Road Transport Authority (RTA), responsible for developing and implementing the Road Transport Policy, specification of vehicle standards, licensing of vehicles, licensing of drivers, and monitoring the Road Transport Sector and its pricing policies; the establishment of a clear set of safety, energy and environmental standards, licensing requirements for vehicles, drivers, transportation service, firms, traffic regulations etc., the development of comprehensive and effective enforcement programmes through clear schedules setting fines and penalties for violations of standards and traffic laws; the creation of a special corps of traffic wardens and public information campaigns; encouragement and promotion of the private sector in road transport related activities; the development of private maintenance and inspection services, and contracting of maintenance services for government vehicles; and the initiation of measures to privatize the Road Transport Corporation. The plans of action envisaged include the creation of a Road Transport Authority (RTA), a review of road transport legislation and the setting up of standards and regulations which will cover the following areas: minimal standards for imported new and used automotive vehicles; standards for imported automotive parts: standards for imported automotive fuels, safety, energy, and environmental standards for automotive vehicles (private cars, taxis, vans, light lorries, heavy lorries, buses), including standards for axle loads, trar-sportation of liquids and hazardous materials; a programme for the certification of approved maintenance and repair facilities and inspection stations; criteria for the certification of road transport carries, and traffic laws and regulations. A study is to be undertaking on the appropriate pricing of user fees for vehicle licenses and registration, vehicle inspection fees, drivers licenses, business licenses for certified inspection centres and maintenance shops set to fully cover the regulatory agency's expenses. In addition, another study will be commissioned on the appropriate pricing, regulation, and guidelines for transport services (taxis, intra-urban buses, inter-urban buses, road freight, etc.) Private sector development will be encouraged through the privatization of the Road Transport Corporation (within six months); the promotion of the development of certified private automotive inspection centres to verify vehicle compliance with emission standards, mechanical fitness, etc.; the development of a private competitive automotive insurance industry; the development, through duty-free concessions, of private automotive maintenance, repair and rehabilitation shops and stations; and the contracting of maintenance and repair of government vehicles to private facilities. In the area of intemational maritime cooperation, the relevant intemational standards on safety and the environment will be ratified and implemented; intemational cooperation with multilateral agencies - UNCTAD, the International Maritime Organization (IMO), the Regional Maritime Academy, and the Ports Management Association will be enhanced; and regional cooperation (through MINCOMAR), will be strengthened. Air Trasport Policy. The main thrust of the air transport sector is on the provision of an adequate, safe, secure, reliable, efficient, affordable and sustainable air transport service, in support of the country's programme of economic and social development. The achievement of the above will facilitate the development of Sierra Leone's intemational trade; contribute to improving the business climate by facilitating the movement of national and intemational business executives; facilitate the development of intemational tourism in Sierra Leone and promote tourism, especially in areas like the Gola Forest, Lake Sonfon, Outamba Kilimi Game Reserve, Bonthe, Kabala, etc.; develop intemational technical cooperation in aviation; facilitate trade and economic integration within the West Africa subregion; contribute to a better integration of the national economy; and facilitate commerce, particularly the evacuation o huigh value precious minerals from the interior of the country. Under the proposed Transport Sector Project, govenmment will restructure and reorganize the overall administration of the air transport subsector; create a semi-autonomous Civil Aviation Unit, with funding from user fees; strengthen the Sierra Leone Airport Authoonty, as a semi-autonomous, self sustained provider of airport infrastructure services, with funding from airport user fees; investigate areas that can be run by the private sector; exploit intemational traffic rights and improve intemational air service to Sierra Leone through inter-line agreements and joint-venture agreements between Sierra Leone National Airlines and foreign airline partners; maintain Lungi Inteational Airport to ICAO standards, maintain Hastings airport to acceptable standards; and improve access from Freetown to Lungi Airport. In order to achieve these objectives, government will implement the following lines of action: commission a feasibility and cost/benefit analysis of restructuring the Directorate of Civil Aviation and transform it into an autonomous Civil Aviation Agency financed with (a portion of) the proceeds of fees generated from aviation; amend Civil Aviation Legislation to reflect the reform of the Civil Aviation administration; review existing multi-lateral treaties and agreements (ICAO, etc.); examine existing bilateral agreements on intemational traffic rights; negotiate bilateral agreement with other countries to develop intemational scheduled traffic; develop a liberal policy with respect to foreign charter airlines; and develop a liberal policy with respect to foreign freight. Government will also assess the situation of other domestic regional airfields; commission a study on the feasibility of redeveloping a schedule domestic air service; and, in conjunction with the local communities and the private sector, rehabilitate provincial airfield; and develop policy with respect to domestic air taxis.

A. ROAD REHABILITATION COMPONENT 2. Two typical road sections totaling 77 km to be rehabilitated at an estimated cost of $2 million were analyzed with the Highway Design and Maintenance Model m (HDM) to verify analyses carried out for SLRA by various consultants. The programmed works include reshaping, spot regravelling, and deferred maintenance. Table 1-a summarizes the road characteristics. 3. The economic benefits are calculated by estimating savings in vehicle operating costs (VOCs) and maintenance costs. Benefits to road users were computed on the basis of the consumer surplus, taken as half the unit VOCs reduction times the generated traffic. The economic indicators calculated are the net present value (NPV) and the internal rates of return (EIRR), using economic user costs and investment costs. 4. Altemative civil works that were evaluated ranged from minimal routine maintenance on the existing roads to pavement rehabilitation or complete reconstruction of the road. Available data on the existing conditions of the roads showed that most roads under consideration were in poor or very poor condition with roughness values in excess of IRI 8.5. Hence, for these roads, alternatives involving only resurfacing options such as resealing or thin overlays, were technically ruled out. For unpaved roads, rehabilitation of at least portions of the roadbed prior to regravelling is required. 5. Costs were considered in both financial and economic terms (after adjusting for taxes and duties). The highly deteriorated condition of many roads causes VOCs to be very high, but lacking viable altemate routes, users cannot avoid such costs. Some reduction in trips has undoubtedly occurred because of poor road conditions. Consequently, rehabilitation and a return to nomnal traffic pattems after the security situation improves will lead to higher traffic. Therefore, initial traffic increase is assumed to be as high as 30% for light vehicles. Estimated future traffic growth in Sierra Leone ranges from 3% to 6% per annum depending on vehicle type for the first five years of the analysis period; it drops to a steady 3% for all vehicle types thereafter. 6. Table 1-b presents a summary of the economic analysis of the entire road investment component of the Credit, totaling 1,027 km and $9.55 million. The result of the sensitivity analysis using a 10% cost-overrun and an implementation delay by one year is summarized in Table 1-c, which shows that the base EIRR decreases from 25% to 22% with the cost-overrun and to 17% with the implementation delay. The proposed Transport Sector Project has been placed under environmental category B, as consistent with the Operational Directive 4.01, Annex E: Environmental Assessment. In accordance with the directive, an environmental assessment was carried-out for the proposed project and in addition, a specific study on the port rehabilitation was prepared. The final report containing an environmental analysis and a mitigation plan addressing the environmental impact of the project was presented to IDA in June 1995 and the final draft of the Port Rehabilitation Study was presented to IDA in January 1996 (see Project File). The main environmental impacts incurred under the project are due to the following project components: (1) the rehabilitation and maintenance of roads; (2) the rehabilitation of the Freetown Port; (3) the improvement of the existing port; and (4) the improvement of landing facilities in inland and coastal waterways. The improvement of the Freetown Airport is not expected to incur any significant environmental impacts. The TSP will include the appointment of an environmental coordinator at the CMU from MCTE's Environmental Department to coordinate the environmental activities in the ministry with other institutions. Rehabilitation and Maintenance of Roads 2. Environmental Impact. The program for periodic and routine maintenance and rehabilitation of the public road network will have several environmental impacts: * soil erosion: the planned works under this component will cause some disruption to the vegetation cover, which will make the uppermost soil layers susceptible to erosion during times of heavy rainfall, particularly on slopes and hilly areas; * potential disturbance to protected areas: some of the road sections under the TSP interfere with protected forests; sand resources: sand for the construction works is extracted from sandy beaches at the peninsula. This results in coastal erosion and conflicts with tourism interests and coastal settlements. 3. Mitization Measures. Appropriate mitigation measures will minimize the negative impact on the environment. * Soil erosion from road construction works can be reduced by several means: land clearance during construction works can be minimized by: minimizing the width of the working zone; utilizing the ditched-up
 94 Annex 6-2 Page 2 of 8 material from side drains as road construction material instead of using borrow pits (depending on the properties of the soil material); and establishing borrow pits close to the roads to avoid the construction of significant sections of temporary roads; - the roads can be designed to protect the road and surrounding areas against erosion. Possible protection measures include: reinforcement of cut slopes by introducing steps each of which having drain ditches, reinforcement of filled slopes and embankments by adding excess fill and subsequent compaction; strengthening of slope surfaces by plarnting grass; implementation of proper road drain systems, including side drains, culverts and possibly outlets at appropriate intervals; and preventing drains against collapsing by strengthening the drain surface (e.g. by planting grass and in some cases by surfacing the drains with concrete). * Potential disturbance to protected areas: the exact extent of interference with protected areas has to be clarified dunng the design phase, and a specific mitigation plan must be prepared to remediate the potential conflicts between road works and protected nature. SLRA must inspect the road work to ensure that the work comply with the prescribed mitigative procedures. Realignment of the road may be considered. v Sand resources: the coastal erosion can be reduced by implementing coast protection, such as groynes, at regular intervals. 4. Iumpact on Human Safety. Labor based road work constitutes a considerable occupational health risk due to several factors, including difficult physical working conditions, exposure to dust and bituminous vapors, and exposure to vibrations and noise from machines. Overall, the road improvements will introduce an increased risk of accidents due to a generally higher speed of the motorized traffic and due to an expected increase in traffic amounts. 5. Mitigation Measures. Measures to reduce occupational health and safety risks include adequate training and education of personnel, use of appropriate personal protective equipment, dust suppression during dry seasons, maintenance of facilities and equipment of designed or regulated level of performance, and proper operational procedures and occupational health standards. Measures to mitigate adverse effects include separation of non-motorized traffic from the motorized by establishment of footpaths, establishment of lay-bys for buses and taxis to prevent against traffic congestion, introduction of speed reduction measures in town and village streets, and proper road marking. In addition surfacing of town and village roads will allow a more uniform speed and partially prevent dust generation. Traffic safety measures should be particularly addressed for town and village roads and heavily trafficked trunk roads. Road Transport 6. It is recommended that an environmental unit be set-up under the RTA to meet the most urgent demands for environmental protection capability in road transport planning and management. The following actions are recommended: * appointment of an environmental specialist to address the following issues: (1) road transport planning and management; (2) general quality standards for imported second hand vehicles, including emission standards, (3) fuel quality standards; (4) traffic safety measures; and (5) coordination of actions and policies with the environmental coordinator at the CMU; * training of the environmental specialist to achieve adequate qualifications; * workshops and/or seminars for management and staff at RTA to increase environmental awareness; and * technical assistance to implement and monitor the proposed actions. 8. The tasks of the environmental unit at the RTA will include among other things: preparation of environmental standards for vehicle emissions, fuel quality, etc. to be approved by the Environmental Protection Secretariat (EPS); performance of workshops, seminars and training in accordance with the proposed institutional strengthening actions; * preparation of environmental terms for the proposed vehicle examination centers and subsequent supervision and control thereof; * proposal of incentives to encourage vehicle operators to adopt standards; and * preparation of terms of reference for specific studies, including a transport planning and management study for Freetown. The Rehabilitation of the Freetown Port 9. The port rehabilitation component covers the rehabilitation of port roads, storage areas, sheds and equipment, investigation of the quay wall and coping, slipway repair and paving of the container stacking area. A separate port rehabilitation study was executed as part of the TSP (see Project File). The project components are not expected to have any significant impact on the surrounding land and water. Diving inspections to examine the current conditions along the quay have indicated that beside some floating garbage, no visible sign of pollution was observed and that there was some marine life present in the waters. 10. The potential sources of pollution within the port are discharges from industrial activity, workshops and shipyards, loading and unloading of ships, dredging and dumping of material from the port. The level of discharges caused by industrial activity, workshops and shipyards, and the loading and unloading of ships might rise slightly due to increased activity in the port area once the
 96 Annex 6-2 Page 4 of 8 rehabilitation is begun and the port facility is enhanced. In particular, the likelihood of an oil spill will increase. The level of dredging is not expected to increase and the risk of hazardous substances accumulating in the in the sediment is small. 11. A system of procedures for collecting the sewage, solid waste, and waste oil will be put in place according to the increase in activities in the port. The following activities will be carried out: * establishment of oil waste reception and treatment facilities at the port; * implementation of an oil spill contingency plan for Sierra Leone; the Oil Spill Contingency Plan for Freetown and Environs was prepared in November 1994. The plan details procedures to be followed for identification of risks and monitoring, as well as for response strategies; however, the necessary equipment remains to be acquired, * implementation of proper operational procedures, occupational health and safety procedures and hazard management procedures, and * clean-up of port areas-on-shore as well as off-shore; including removal of scrap and wrecks and clean-up of contaminated soil and sediments. In addition, a study to examine the potential impact of port activities on spawning and fishing areas will be undertaken. The Coastal and River Transport Component 12. Environmental Impact. A number of potentially severe adverse environmental impacts can be expected from various activities under this investment package which it is essential to address: possible deepening, widening and change of the course of a river will increase the drainage of the catchment area, thereby changing the water-balance of the catchment area with potentially severe permanent effects on wetland as well as agricultural, grassland, and forest ecology. This could be the case for the Sewa and the Moa rivers in the eastem part of Sierra Leone. The catchment area of Moa River contains a national wild life sanctuary which could be adversely affected by an altered water balance. The catchment area of Sewa river includes protected forests and large areas of inland swamps, which are vulnerable to changes in the water balance; * these effects are particularly significant for protected forest and other types of protected nature areas in Sierra Leone. Rivers and estuaries to be prepared or improved for inland navigation are not yet determined. Therefore, it is not clear whether protected forests or other nature reserves in certain catchment areas will be affected; * the change in the hydrological characteristics of rivers may also increase the risk of river bank erosion and subsequent flooding of nearby areas;
 97 Annex 6-2 Page 5 of 8 * river and estuarine flora and fauna may be affected due to several factors, including permanent changes of hydrological nature, siltation from dredging activities, possible change in salinity of estuaries due to increased supply of fresh water to estuaries and due to emissions of pollution, noise, and vibrations from the mantime traffic, * disposal (upland disposal or off-shore dumping) of dredged sediments may cause varying effects on ecological habitats; * improvement of river and coastal transport will, other things being equal, increase the nrsk of oil spills and accidents in rivers and estuaries; * locally, the improvement of ports and jetties may imply adverse environmental effects to be mitigated. 13. Proposed Actions. Adequate reception and treatment facilities for oily waste are required as an indispensable part of the marine infrastructure development as well as the development of a set of emergency response actions to unintentional oil spills an accidents. Special attention should be paid to the ecologically sensitive wetland areas, such as the extensive mangrove swamps in the Bronte area and the swamp areas along the Sewa River. Particularly, the requirement of oily waste reception and treatment facilities should be addressed along the potential operation and management of hazardous goods. 14. Stakeholder participation will be sought at every level of project implementation. SLRA will be the agency responsible for implementing this component. It will hire local staff to conduct the necessary studies to identify mitigation plans and will ensure that local and national stakeholders participate in defining the terms of reference for the studies and plans. The studies for each project subcomponent will cover the issues of environmental sustainability, cost recovery, and organizational management. IDA will examine and approve the organization, implementation, and environmental mitigation aspect of each sub-component prior to disbursement. Improvement of Freetown Airport 15. The airport component of the TSP includes runway edge light repair, runway pavement evaluation, procurement of fire fighting and rescue equipment and perimeter fencing. No significant environmental impacts are likely to occur in relation to the proposed activities. Coordination of Environmental Activities 16. All implementing agencies in the TSP, except for the SLRA, are part of the MCTE, which will ensure that the environmental mitigation plan and other related activities will be closely monitored and coordinated. To coordinate the environmental activities under the TSP, it is recommended that an environmental coordinator be attached to the CMU from MCTE's Environmental Department. The tasks of the coordinator will include among other things: * coordination of environmental activities under the TSP, including regular joint meetings with the staff handling environmental issues at the implementing agencies;

Mitigation Plan 17. A draft plan to mitigate adverse effects of the TSP has been prepared and will be financed under the project. The plan proposes legal, institutional strengthening, training, and technical measures to be incorporated in the TSP. It has been approved by the MCTE. 18. Legal Measures. The following legal measures are recommended: * preparation of environmental guidelines regarding road rehabilitation and maintenance works; * preparation of proper standards for emission factors and noise from vehicles; * preparation of fuel quality criteria; * preparation of a program for vehicle emission control and fuel quality control; * preparation of proper operational procedures and occupational health and safety procedures in connection with road works, vehicle examnination centers, port, and airport operations; and * preparation of adequate guidelines and emergency response action plans regarding rehabilitation of Freetown Port which is in accordance with the recommendations made in the coastal and river transport study. 19. doc.abstracts: The development objectives of the Transport Sector Project are to: 1) support the implementation of the new transport sector policy and strategy; 2) expand the successful home-grown process of institutional reform and strengthening; and 3) increase the use of labor-intensive methods in road works and road maintenance. The specific project aims are: 1) sector/investment planning; 2) private participation; 3) regulatory capacity (management of road transport and alleviation of urban traffic congestion); 4) maritime transport; and 5) civil aviation safety. The project will consist of three main components: 1) capacity building; 2) parastatal restructuring and privatization; and 3) investment.
